Novel characteristics of graphene have captured great attention of researchers for energy technology applications. Incorporation of graphene related hybrid and composite materials have demonstrated high performance and durability for fuel cell energy conversion devices. This article overviews graphene based materials for fuel cell technology applications such as electrodes additives, bipolar plates and proton conducting electrolyte membrane. The graphene dispersion over electrodes has revealed enhanced exposure of electrochemically active surface area for improved electro-catalytic activity towards fuel oxidation and oxidant reduction reactions. The issue of device stack durability and degraded performance due to corrosion of bipolar plates is discussed by incorporating graphene based materials. In proton exchange membrane devices, graphene as an electrolyte has shown an excellent performance towards high ionic conductivity and power density. The graphene incorporation in fuel cell devices has exhibited commendable performance and has bright future for commercial applications. Graphical abstract The rise of graphene in fuel cell technology is discussed. Special emphasis is devoted to pristine and doped graphene composites for electrode additives, bipolar plates and proton conducting electrolyte membrane for fuel cell technology. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Graphene Fuel cell Electro-catalyst Power density Durability 1 Introduction Current increased energy demands and sustainable development goals require more efficient, cost effective and eco-friendly energy conversion systems for domestic and commercial applications [1]. The available renewable and non-renewable energy conversion systems are insufficient and have drawbacks. Non-renewable oil, gas and coal driven energy systems have exhibited low performance, high cost, pollution, global warming and resources depletion. On the other hand, environment friendly renewable hydropower, solar cell, geothermal and biomass energy conversion systems have demonstrated low performance to cost ratio e.g. best power conversion efficiency (PCE) achieved for a solar cell is ∼25% [2]. Therefore, worldwide research is underway to explore more efficient, cost effective and sustainable energy resources and conversion systems. The discovery of fuel cell has successfully overcome the above mentioned issues by renewable electrochemical energy conversion mechanism. Therefore, fuel cell energy conversion devices are of prime interest for future applications [3–11]. Simple fuel cell device consume hydrogen rich fuel and an oxidant to produce combined heat and electrical power (CHP) through electrochemical process with ecofriendly byproducts [12,13]. Such CHP systems have achieved highest PCE of 83%, being paramount among more efficient energy conversion systems [14]. In addition, no involvement of moving parts in fuel cells requires minimal maintenance, which reduces life cycle costs of energy production. The byproduct formed during energy conversion is usually water which can be further utilized for various purposes [15]. Therefore, fuel cell can be opted for future domestic and commercial energy production systems. William Grove in 1839 discovered fuel cell effect during a chemically water splitting process into hydrogen and oxygen by an applied electric field. It was revealed that the electric current can be produced by combining same elements [16]. Experimental setup for both electrochemical reactions is schematically drawn in Fig. 1 (a) and (b). Reaction of simple fuel cell hydrogen fuel device with acidic electrolyte is as under. At anode 2 H 2 → 4 H + + 4 e − At cathode O 2 + 4 e − + 4 H + → 2 H 2 O The simplest fuel cell device comprises of three components, an electrolyte membrane packed between two thin, spongy anode and cathode [16], schematically presented in Fig. 2 . Hydrogen fuel is provided over the porous surface of anode, where an electrocatalyst splits the hydrogen atoms into electron (e−) and proton (H+) [14]. These electrons cannot pass the electrolyte membrane and follow a circuit to reach the cathode on the other side while protons penetrate through electrolyte to cathode. At cathode, electrons and protons recombine to produce hydrogen before oxygen is allowed over the cathode surface. The oxygen on cathode reacts with the coming hydrogen molecules yielding water. The electrical energy produced through this electrochemical process is measured at load in the circuit [14]. Primarily, the performance of such devices is greatly influenced by the electrical properties and morphology of active materials employed for device assembly. Hence, researchers have been looking for novel materials with exceptional properties and remarkable applications in FC technology. In this regard, although scientists have investigated a number of materials for low cost metal electrodes, catalysts and electrolytes, yet the performance and environmental threats remained there. Apart from these materials for electrochemical processes, carbon based materials in addition to their abundance, stability, processibilty and eco-friendliness, have demonstrated unique properties and promising applications for such CHP systems [15,17–19]. Different arrangements of carbon atoms resulted as many allotropes like graphene (Gr), carbon nanotubes (CNTs), fullerene, graphite and diamond. Graphene being 2D material enjoys the superiority over 0D, 1D and 3D carbon structures for owing astounding electrochemistry. Notable characteristics of graphene over other carbon structures are broader specific surface area, high conductivity, ballistic carrier mobility and superior electro-activity [20,21]. Although, novel CNTs, fullerene and carbon quantum dots are competitors of graphene yet scalability and quality are the issues to be addressed. Therefore, graphene surpassing carbon family members due to excellent electrochemistry is propitious contender for electrochemical applications. Table 1 summarizes the properties of different carbon materials. Since the discovery of graphene in 2004 by Geim and Novoselov, it has become a shining star among other materials [22]. For this reason, many of the chemist, physicist, engineers and material scientists for the last decade have dedicated their time to explore graphene, its properties and applications [22–25]. The 2D flat hexagonally arranged carbon atoms in graphene, exhibit sp 2 hybridization with stronger in plane σc-c bonding than out of plane π bonding. As a result, a delocalized network of electrons enhances electron conductivity and offers lowered interface between the graphene layers and substrate [9]. Furthermore, replacement of a carbon atom with some other atoms (B, N, S and P) increase conductivity and enhance electrochemical properties of graphene [26–29]. Similarly, graphene based nanocomposites like alloys, polymer materials, metals, metal oxides and sulphides have potential applications for CHP systems [30–44]. Therefore, intrinsic and extrinsic properties of graphene and derived materials of lower cost, high performance and eco-friendliness are of prime interest for electrochemical energy conversion systems [7,45]. The utilization of graphene considerably overcome the drawbacks of different fuel cell devices and may be opted as porous electrodes, electrocatalyst and bipolar plates for enhanced efficiency and durability of the devices. This article provides brief overview of graphene based fuel cell devices. 2 Fuel cell technology 2.1 Working principle Cogeneration unit of fuel cell device transform the hydrogen energy into heat and electrical energy [12,13]. Mostly, hydrogen provided over the anode is utilized as fuel while cathode is fed by some oxidant. Resulting hydrogen oxidation (HOR) and oxygen reduction reactions (ORR), arising on anode and cathode polarizes the cell [13]. The current produced during the reactions is measured at the load connected externally. Under standard temperature and pressure conditions, and taking heat produced into account, theoretically proposed PCE of fuel cell is 83%. For such conditions, 1.23 V of open circuit voltage (OCV) has been achieved without any electrical loss. However, commercially available devices are not so efficient and have low OCV. This lower performance of the FC device is ascribed to varying operational conditions such as temperature and pressure. Furthermore, the voltage losses during the operation reduce the electrode potential and degrade efficiency drastically. The several dynamics of electrochemical reactions which include the rates and electrochemistry of reactions, the inability of the gases to reach the reaction active site, low internal electrical currents and high resistance of electrodes and crossover effect are responsible for arising performance issues in fuel cell devices [12]. Additionally, Ohmic losses along with concentration and activation polarization also affect the efficiency of the cell. The V–I polarization plot based over whole extent of power for fuel cell device characterizes and analyzes the phenomena listed above [46]. Basic parameters for fuel cell device performance evaluation include open circuit voltage, current density, Tafel slope, transfer coefficient, maximum power density and efficiency. The voltage-current polarization curve is obtained by using the relation E = E r − RT α F ln ( i + i loss i 0 ) − RT nF ln ( i L i L − i ) − i R int Where E r represents reversible potential at STP conditions, T defines operational temperature, R indicates ideal gas constant, α denotes transfer coefficient, i 0 specifies exchange current density, i loss designates current loss, i L entitles limiting current density, F symbolizes Faraday's constant, n labels number of electrons per H2 molecule, and R int indicates internal resistance [12]. Electrochemical conversion of energy in fuel cell requires proper designing of the device. A fuel cell assemblage unifies membrane electrode assemblies (MEAs), bipolar plates, current collectors and support essentials [47]. Such membrane electrode assembly is portrayed schematically in Fig. 3 (a) and (b). The components assembled in Fig. 3(b) are necessary for fuel cell operation and possess the functionalities required for electrochemical processes [48]. The main processes in the fuel cell are constant flow rate of fuel and oxidant gases over the channel of bipolar plates and electrodes, catalysis for HOR and ORR, transfer of positively charged ions through the membrane and electron transference through the externally attached supporting elements, removal of unused gases and byproducts [12]. 2.2 Classification of fuel cell technology Generally, fuel cells are categorized for operating temperatures, fuels and oxidants, and the type of electrolyte employed. Temperature dependent FC devices are defined for their low and high operating temperatures respectively while hydrogen-oxygen and ammonia-air fuel cells are examples of devices based on specific fuel and oxidant. On the basis of most general ground for classification of fuel cells, some typical fuel cells based on different electrolytes are alkaline, phosphoric acid, proton exchange membrane, molten carbonate, solid oxide and micro-solid oxide fuel cells [13,49,50]. The type device determines the electrochemistry and kinetics of reactions arising in the cell, the type of catalysts to be employed, operational temperature, fuel compatibility and other operational parameters. Table 2 summarizes the comparative analysis of different fuel cells based on different electrolytes. 2.2.1 Alkaline fuel cells (AFCs) AFCs utilizes alkaline electrolyte such as concentrated solution (40%) of KOH as electrolyte membrane. Basic principle of AFC is that negative (OH−) ions are transferred to the anode through the electrolyte, associate with hydrogen producing water and generating negatively charged electrons. A variety of metals and noble metals like Ni, Pt etc. and corresponding oxides have been investigated for catalysis over porous electrodes to speed up the reaction [51]. Apart from the fact that high performance of 60% is achieved for AFC at ∼200 °C, however operational range for AFCs is marked in range 100–250 °C. The main advantage of AFCs is its high oxide reduction reaction. In contrast, drawback of AFCs is the easy infection by carbon oxides. In fact a minute quantity of carbon oxides in operating environment influence the cell operation by combining with KOH and hence, increasing the resistance [16]. To avoid such situations, hydrogen and oxygen must be purified or pure reactant gases must be supplied. Well known applications of AFCs are first manned spacecraft e.g. Apollo and Shuttle Orbiter craft. 2.2.2 Phosphoric acid fuel cells (PAFCs) In PAFCs an inorganic, chemically and thermally stable liquid phosphoric acid (H3PO4) is employed as an electrolyte. The operation of PAFCs involves the transfer of positively charged (H+) ions via electrolyte to the cathode. The reaction of (H+) ions with electrons and oxygen at cathode yield heat and water. A stack assembly of PAFCs include graphite based bipolar plates, Pt/C catalyst over carbon electrode also working as diffusion layer [51]. The efficiency of PAFCs ranges from 40% for electricity alone to 80% for cogeneration of electricity and heat. Operational temperatures for PAFCs are from 150 to 220 °C. At such temperatures, the stack may overheat due to liquefied electrolyte; therefore some active mechanism is required to prevent warmness and depletion of electrolyte. The advantages of PAFCs include high stability, high resistance to contaminants, higher conductivity and higher power for commercial applications [52]. 2.2.3 Proton exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs) A solid polymer electrolyte is used in PEMFCs as proton exchange membrane with platinum electrodes [16]. The electrolyte is usually perfluorosulfonated acid (PFSA) based polymer which conduct protons. The catalyst used is platinum/carbon paste for pure hydrogen fuel, and Pt–Ru alloy if fuel contain CO2 contaminants [12]. Moreover, two porous carbon based gas diffusion electrodes and graphite based bipolar plates are also used. Such fuel cells may operate under low as well as high temperatures ranging from 80 °C to 200 °C [53–63]. PEMFCs are ∼40%–50% efficient. Drawback of being susceptible to be poisoned by CO, has been overcome by the development of high temperature PEMFCs [62,64]. The electrolytes used in high temperature PEMFCs include polybenzimidazoles (PBI and sulfonated poly (ether sulfone). Simple design, easy manufacturing, cost effectiveness and durability are the key features which make PEMFCs most commonly used fuel cells [65,66]. 2.2.4 Molten carbonate fuel cells (MCFCs) The MCFCs, high temperature FC devices use a combination of alkalis and molten carbonates salt as electrolyte [12]. In MCFCs, negative ions are transferred by penetrating the membrane to anode. On anode, the joining electrons with hydrogen produce water and electrons. At higher operating temperatures (600 °C–700 °C) conductive slats are formed by molten carbonates and therefore, MCFCs do not require reformers and precious noble metal (Pt, Ni) catalysts. The fuel (natural or synthetic gas) reforms itself at high temperatures within a FC device by the progression termed self-reforming [67]. The higher operating temperatures and corrosive electrolytes also have some drawbacks e.g. increased corrosion and decreased device life. The maximum efficiency that may be obtained for MCFCs ranges between 60% and 80%. MCFCs are in trial period for commercial applications [12]. 2.2.5 Solid oxide fuel cells (SOFCs) SOFCs devices have a solid and nonporous metal oxide (e.g. zirconium oxide stabilized with yttrium oxide (YSZ)) ceramic electrolyte [12]. In SOFCs, negative charged ions are transferred to the anode by penetration from the membrane, producing water and electrons upon reactions with hydrogen. Such electrochemical conversion devices operate at broad temperature range of 600 °C–1000 °C, where ions are conducted by oxide. Despite the high operating temperatures, SOFCs do not transform the solid state. At such high working temperatures, SOFCs can achieve increased reaction rate without using costly metallic catalysts. Furthermore, natural gas may be utilized directly as fuel without external reformer as gases are reformed internally at higher working temperatures [16]. The maximum PCE of 50%–60% can be achieved for SOFCs. Other than Y2O3 stabilized ZrO2, BiMeVOX (Bi-bismuth, Me-additive metal, V-vanadium, OX-oxygen) can also be used as an electrolyte in SOFCs [68]. These devices are one of the most famous among the commercialized fuel cells devices and have applications from micro to several MW power [50,69]. Fig. 4 presents the operation conditions for a class of fuel cells. 3 Graphene Graphene, a flat atomically thick membrane of carbon, since its discovery in 2004 has showcases exclusive electronic and electrochemical characteristics with potential applications [22]. Two dimensionally arranged honeycomb lattice of graphene is a unit cell of all other dimensionalities of carbonaceous materials like fullerene (0D), carbon nanotube (1D) and graphite (3D) [70]. The thickness dependent electronic properties of graphene are quite different from bulk counterpart graphite. A graphene layer is zero band gap semi-conductor with high carrier mobility (up to 100,000 cm2 V−1 s−1) at relativistic speed ∼106 m s−1 [71,72]. Additionally, room temperature quantum Hall effect (QHE), ambipolar electric field effect and electron wave propagation in graphene makes it superior to other carbonaceous materials [73]. On the other hand in semiconducting bilayer graphene, charge carriers obey parabolic energy distribution and exhibits tunable zero band gap, which can be modified by breaking the symmetry between the adjacent layers [74]. In tri-layer graphene, the additional third layer transforms the semiconducting nature to semi-metallic through band overlapping. The overlapping of bands is tunable by externally applied electric field [75]. The multilayer graphene exhibits the listed properties only with the Bernal ABAB stacking of natural graphite. In addition, interlayer interaction, defects, layer arrangement and stacking order i.e. angular mis-orientation or lateral translation, are other factors affecting the properties of multilayer graphene [76]. The synthesis methods also influence the properties of graphene related materials i.e. physical method to produce graphene nanoribbons causes defects which reduces device performance [75,77]. The strategies generally adopted to produce graphene are categorized as top-down and bottom-up routes. In top-down approach, single and multilayer graphene is exfoliated from bulk graphite material. The most demonstrative example of top-down technique is the exfoliation of graphite oxide from bulk graphite material [23,78]. Similarly, liquid phase exfoliation [79], electrochemical exfoliation [78] and graphite intercalation compounds (GICs) [80] belong to top-down approach. Although, top-down technique is suitable for low cost and mass production yet single layer graphene with high quality is not achievable [1]. In contrast, bottom-up approach involves graphene growth from organic precursors i.e. hydrocarbons [81]. Bottom-up approaches which have been utilized for graphene synthesis include chemical vapor deposition (CVD) [24] and epitaxial growth [82]. The CVD grown graphene have exhibited high quality and large effective surface area with applications as transparent electrodes [83]. Still, the high cost and mass production are issues to be addressed. Different schemes including mechanical exfoliation [22,84,85], epitaxial growth [85,86], unrolling CNTs [87] and chemical reduction [88] have been demonstrated to synthesize graphene and composites. 4 Graphene for electrochemical energy devices Amongst variety of potential applications, electrochemistry of graphene suggests it as a strong candidate for electrochemical devices. Several techniques have been employed to explore the electrochemistry of graphene, such as chronocoulometry, voltammograms and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy. The electrochemistry of graphene has uncovered its certain electrochemical features which include but not limited to morphology, electro-activity, improved charge transfer kinetics and electrocatalysis of molecules [89,90]. The most important electrochemical aspect of graphene is large electrochemically active surface area. Chronocoulometric studies for the reduction of 1 mM K3Fe(CN)6 with 2 M KCl at dissimilar electrodes resulted as the area of electrodes, graphite/glassy carbon (0.0560 cm2) < glassy carbon (0.0706 cm2) < graphene/glassy carbon (0.092 cm2) [90]. Further, electrochemical impedance spectroscopy revealed 13 times more capacitance of graphene based electrode than glassy carbon [89]. Very large physical surface area and sp2 hybridization of carbon atoms in graphene also contribute to high capacitance values. Voltammograms of Ru (NH3)6 3+/2+, Fe(CN)6 3 − /4−,Fe3+/2+, and dopamine (DA) redox systems identified fast charge transfer kinetics of graphene electrodes [89,91]. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy has revealed superior charge transfer characteristics for graphene over glassy carbon and graphite/(glassy carbon) electrodes. Graphene, with such diversified admirable characteristics have been employed in electrochemical devices like fuel cells, super capacitors and batteries. The coming sections overview the graphene applications in the fuel cells for low cost, high performing and durable devices for domestic and commercial applications. 4.1 Graphene in conductive electrodes Superior characteristics of graphene make it a perfect choice as electro-conductive electrode for fuel cells. Numerous studies have implied comparable results by using graphene as catalyst support, additive and electrodes in FC technology [92–102]. Graphene may be an additive to electrode either individually or with other organic/inorganic materials. It may be added to each of electrodes i.e. cathode and anode for fuel oxidation reaction (FOR) and oxygen reduction reactions (ORR). 4.1.1 Graphene for enhanced oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) The efficiency of FCs is significantly dependent upon reactions at the electrodes. For example, lower experimental performance of fuel cell than theoretically predicted is mainly due to the slow ORR at cathode. Therefore, efficient energy conversion FC devices demand for electrochemically more active electro-catalysts [7,103,104]. Although conventionally used Pt-based electrocatalyst manifested considerable electro-activity for ORR, still there are some issues. Along with high prices and low reserves of Pt, the effects of fuel crossover between the electrodes through the membrane and CO poisoning limits the device performance [8,105,106]. To overcome these hinders, low cost, metal and metal free electro-catalysts with large surface areas for enhanced ORR have been a topic of interest for the scientists [107]. Many studies recommend graphene for enhanced ORR at cathode, improving fuel cell efficiency [27,108–119]. The functionalization of graphene by adsorption of poly (diallyldimethylammonium chloride) (PDDA), showed enhanced electro-catalytic activity for ORR through fast carrier transport between graphene and PDDA [120,121]. The result suggests that intermolecular charge transfer is a cost effective simple technique to grow carbon based metal free ORR. Schematic presentation of the process and results are provided in Fig. 5 . Vinyan et al. uniformly dispersed Pt and Pt-Co alloy nanoparticles (NPs) on N-doped hydrogen exfoliated graphene (N-HEG) [122]. The Pt/N-HEG and Pt3Co/N-HEG electro-catalytic characteristics were studied for PEMFC performance. In the absence of back pressure, at 60 °C the Pt/N-HEG and Pt3Co/N-HEG as cathode electro-catalyst produced the maximum power densities of 512 and 805 mW cm−2. The high power density obtained by Pt3Co/N-HEG is ascribed to the Pt modifications through alloying, N-doping, uniform dispersion of NPs and higher activity of N-HEG. The Pt3Co/N-HEG showed high stability even in acidic media, for strong binding interaction between the NPs and N-HEG. The characteristics curves are drawn in Fig. 6 . Theoretical and experimental work has revealed the incorporation of heteroatoms to carbon atoms in graphene improve the electrochemical characteristics [105]. The increased activity is attributed to higher electro-negativity value of N (3.04) as compared with carbon atoms C (2.55) and creation of increased positive charge density on neighboring carbon atoms in graphene [123]. As a result, greater adsorption of oxygen is achieved [124]. Similarly, doping with atoms of similar electro-negativities as that of carbon atoms (i.e. S ∼ 2.58, Se ∼ 2.55) have unveiled profound results [125]. Improved electro-catalytic activity, durability and tolerance of S/Se doped carbon atoms in alkaline media for ORR is in agreement with the theoretically predicted results [27]. Undoubtedly, the inclusion of foreign atoms into the carbon atoms network in graphene is a practical strategy to obtain improved electro-catalytic activity through increased adsorption of O2 for ORR in fuel cells. Zhang et al. used Ngraphene (NGr) produced with amino functional group for ORR [105]. The NGr improved performance and enhanced tolerance to the fuel. The effect of the nitrogen centers on catalytic activity of cathode for ORR was also analyzed. The results demonstrate that graphitic and amino nitrogen governs the onset potential and carrier transport rate, whereas total amount of graphitic and pyridinic nitrogen determine current density in electro-catalytic activity [123] as presented in Fig. 7 . Similarly, Qu et al. employed CVD-Gr as metal free electrocatalyst for ORR [111]. The resulting N-Gr exhibited improved electrochemical activity, durability and tolerance to fuel than Pt, as depicted in Fig. 8 [111]. Earlier, the study of nitrogen doped carbon nanotubes (N-CNTs) reported that the positive charge density of nitrogen neighboring carbon atoms counterbalances the electron affinity of nitrogen atoms [126]. As a redox cycle, the naturally oxidized carbon atoms are firstly reduced, followed by the oxidation upon the adsorption of O2 [126]. Similarly, nitrogen activated charge imbalance also facilitate ORR at electrode through altering the chemisorption of O2 molecule and weakening the OO bond. Other studies also support NGr for superior electro-activity, low cost and stable ORR applications in electrochemical energy conversion devices [127]. In a work by Yang et al., they studied sulfur doped graphene (S-graphene) for ORR applications [27]. They explored that superior ORR activity of doped graphene do not depend upon the doping material but on the breach of electroneutrlity of the graphitic planes which become the center of O2 catalysis and improves the adsorption of O2. Mehmood et al. reported high performance graphene-based cobalt sulphide composite with high surface area, increased conductivity and functionalized centers for O2 adsorption [39]. Zhang et al. described a novel class of non-noble metallic electro-catalysts based on NGr in composition with iron phthalocyanine (FePc) [7]. The results revealed that NGr with FePc is responsible for increased numbers of catalytically active centers, enhanced catalytic activity, improved conductivity and superior device performance over commercially available Pt/C, shown in Fig. 9 . Zhang et al. further studied the phosphorous incorporation to graphitic plane of graphene and results showed improved device performance in terms of increased ORR on cathode [128]. This improvement in performance is due to the activation of pi-electrons in graphene by the phosphorous atoms. Wu et al. demonstrated unique 3D network of graphene as electro-catalyst which showcases enlarged surface area and multidimensional channel for O2 flow [129]. In future, such networks can support electrochemically active and conductive substrates for more efficient electrochemical devices. Comprehensive literature of graphene based electrocatalyst for ORR is summarized in Table 3 . 4.1.2 Graphene for enhanced fuel oxidation reaction Although, the efficiency of FC device is generally degraded due to poor characteristics of cathode, yet anode characteristics for fuel oxidation can also affect the device efficiency and cost. Nowadays, search for metal free and cheap electrode materials for energy conversion devices is of prime interest. Different carbon materials and their composites have been utilized as anode supporting layers. It was noted that pure graphene forms thick and well-ordered structure during the diffusion layer coating process [164]. As a result low performance of the device was observed. When incorporated with carbon black (CB) and MWCNTs spacer, the porous structure of graphene/CB and graphene/MWCNTs supported Pt anode accelerate the fuel and product diffusion rate, reducing mass transport constraints. Furthermore, high surface area, enhanced stability, improved conductivity and sharp catalytic activity was also demonstrated. The results conclude that best membrane electrode assembly was achieved with 0.25 mg cm−2 catalyst loading which is comparable to graphene free assembly comprised of conventional electrode materials with 0.4 mg cm−2 catalysts loading. Fig. 10 shows comparative polarization curves and corresponding power densities. Woo et al. loaded 40 wt% PtRu onto graphene-Vulcan carbon composite and investigated its electro-catalytic characteristics for anode [165]. Vulcan carbon spacer was used between the graphene flakes to enhance the electrochemical activity of the composite. Famous Hummers technique was employed for GO preparation. The graphene-Vulcan carbon composite synthesis process is elaborated in Fig. 11 (a) and (b). Electrochemical measurements revealed higher electrochemically active surface area for PtRu/GC (79.8 m2 g−1) than PtRu/G (44.6 m2 g−1). The polarization curve evaluations shows PtRu/GC (0.742 W cm−2) as superior to PtRu/C (0.05 W cm−2) and PtRu/G (0.368 W cm−2) as shown in Fig. 11(c). In a nutshell, graphene-Vulcan carbon composite can be opted for anode support in fuel cell devices. The 3D graphene networks have also been investigated over different substrates for fuel cell applications. Yong et al. used PANI hybridized three-dimensional (3D) graphene anode for microbial fuel cell [166]. The 3D graphene was grown through cost effective CVD approach using carbon and ethanol source over Ni foam substrate. The performance tests for graphene/PANI anode were carried out and compared to generally used carbon cloth. Electrochemical studies revealed low sheet resistance (1000 Ω) of graphene/PANI as compared with carbon cloth (2800 Ω). As a result, higher power density 768 W cm−2 was observed, which is significantly greater than carbon cloth 158 W cm−2. Besides, graphene/PANI is low weight and exhibit higher power density than carbon cloth. Fig. 12 represents schematic of 3D graphene/PANI interface with bacteria. The nano-scale Pt/Graphene interactions with corresponding nano-species have resulted with improved performance. A high loading amount 80 wt% of Pt NPs (dimensions <3 nm) over the surface of graphene nano-sheets has shown productive results for methanol (fuel) oxidation reaction (MOR) [167]. A considerably enhanced electrochemically active surface areas (ECSA) (53, 51 and 36 m2 g−1 for 40, 60 and 80 wt% for Pt/GrNS) were obtained, which are superior to conventional Pt/C electrocatalyst. In terms of current density, Pt/GrNS demonstrate three times enhanced results than Pt/C. A recent study of PtPd(nanocubes)/rGO as electrocatalyst shows favorable results for methanol oxidation reaction [168]. Increased negative onset potential, enhanced ECSA and more current density have been observed for PtPd(nanocubes)/rGO than conventional Pt/C and un-supported PtPd nanocubes for MOR. Increased stability during the MOR and durability of device suggest PtPd(nanocubes)/graphene as more stable catalyst for electrochemical devices. A 3D bimetallic hetero-structure supported by graphene nano-sheets also demonstrate improved catalytic activity toward MOR [169]. Metallic Pt NPs synthesized through wet-chemical approach over Pd supported by graphene yield high ECSA nanodendrites. The resulted nanodendrites have porous structure with better dispersion of Pt NPs. The electrochemical characteristics of nanodendrites can be tuned by varying reaction parameters and hence obtaining tunable catalytic activity. Such bimetallic nanodendrites exhibited 3 to 9 times increased catalytic towards MOR than conventional materials. 3D hybrid electrocatalyst composed of Pt/C wrapped in graphene aerogel (Pt/C/GA) has been demonstrated to show high catalytic activity [170]. A facile, simple and low cost hydrothermal route was adopted to synthesize Pt/C/GA electrocatalyst. The Pt/C/GA electrocatalyst revealed high MOR activity with almost 100% performance retention. Pt/C/GA also sustained 84% performance under methanol crossover effect in acidic electrolyte as compared to 60% of Pt/C after 1000 CV cycles. Such super performance of the Pt/C/GA electrocatalyst is assigned by the macroporous structure of graphene aerogel. In another work, Zhao et al. demonstrated Pt/3D-NG electrocatalyst through simple dip coating technique for enhanced oxidation reactions [171]. Commercially available sponge was employed as template for nano graphene sheets and N atoms were incorporated to enhance electrochemical attributes. Usage of sponge reduced the restacking of graphene sheets and improved the overall performance. As-obtained Pt/3D-NG electrocatalyst achieved 2.3 folds more MOR activity and excellent stability. Likewise, Pt/3D-NG electrocatalyst also exhibited more ORR activity in acidic electrolyte. Incorporation of heteroatoms (N atoms) increased the electron density changing atomic charge states, elevating the Fermi band and reducing the band gap which resulted as better electrochemical activity of Pt/3D-NG electrocatalyst [172,173]. Synergy of ultra-fine Pt NPs and N-GA may result as superior electro-catalytic performance. The synergy of Pt NPs and 3D N-GA have confirmed high electrochemical activity achieved by the 3D porous framework, higher electron density induced by the N atoms incorporation and identical distribution of Pt NPs. The Pt/(3D)N-GA exhibited high electro-active area of 90.7 m2 g−1 and more stability as compared to Pt/G and un-doped Pt/(3D)N-GA. A recent study shows N doped graphene aerogel (N-GA) as promising electrocatalyst for ORR and MOR [174]. The as-prepared 3D architecture owe highly active area, porous texture and unique structure. The 3D N-GA electrocatalyst found low half-wave potential about ∼43 mV, four electron transfer scheme, enhanced durability and outstanding fuel tolerance. Rao and coworkers analyzed Pt/GrNs and PtAu/GrNs as catalyst for formic acid oxidation reaction (FAOR) [175]. The performance tests of device at two operating temperatures 303 and 333 K, show better results for Pt/GrNs and PtAu/GrNs as compared with Pt/C catalyst. The polarization curves for comparison are given in Fig. 13 . At 303 K, the maximum power densities of 53, 70 and 136 mW cm−2 were achieved for Pt/C, Pt/graphene and PtAu/graphene, respectively. The results suggest that graphene supported catalytic materials perform better than supported by conventional materials for FAOR. Fan et al. in their work, used graphene supported Pd (Pd/GrNs) for ethanol oxidation reaction (EOR) [176]. The electrochemical studies of Pd/GrNs revealed higher performance as compared to Vulcan XC-72R carbon supported Pd (Pd/VXC). The cyclic voltammetry of both composites is presented in Fig. 14 . The higher peak of Pd/GrNs clearly shows improved performance of the device for Pd/GrNs catalyst. Applications of graphene for FOR are summarized in Table 4 . 4.2 Graphene for bipolar plates applications in fuel cells Operational stability and durability of fuel cell devices is critical for practical applications. Bipolar plates used in fuel cell stacks generally corroded on oxidation and therefore, less stable devices show low performance. The performance of conventionally used copper and nickel bipolar plates decreases gradually with time. On the other side, graphene employed bipolar plates have exhibited more durability and stable operational performance. Therefore, graphene based materials are practical choice as bipolar plates in fuel cells. Lee et al. evaluated the performance of CVD-G coated copper as bipolar plates through current–voltage–power (I–V–P) studies [215]. The results confirmed that graphene coated copper bipolar plate in a single cell have superior performance over pure copper bipolar plate as plotted in Fig. 15 . The degraded efficiency of a single fuel cell device using copper bipolar plate is due to surface oxidation of copper. Furthermore, after 5 h copper bipolar plate shows an increased sheet resistance and low performance. In contrast, graphene coated copper bipolar plate exhibited better performance as compared to the pure copper bipolar plate. Graphene coating prevents the copper plate from oxidation and increases the durability without any degradation in performance. Therefore, graphene coated copper bipolar plate is an adoptable choice for high performance and low cost durable fuel cell device. Kim et al. reported long term operating stability of 3D graphene coated nickel (3D-G Ni) foam [216] for bipolar plate applications. Highly crystalline multilayer 3D graphene coatings were derived from poly (methyl methacrylate) through thermal annealing for short time. After exposure to operational environment, the grown 3D-G Ni foam maintained low corrosion current density as compared to other bipolar plates. Furthermore, a H2/air fuel cell device with 3D-G Ni foam as bipolar plates demonstrated highest power density ∼967 mW cm−2 at cell potential 0.5 V. The results discussed in Fig. 16 , implies that 3D-G can be used as protective layer for durable bipolar plates in high performance fuel cell devices. In paper [217], Kakati et al. reported carbon materials i.e. natural graphite (NG), carbon black, carbon fiber (CF) and graphene based polymer composite for bipolar plates. The performance of the device, electrical conductivity of bipolar plate, corrosion current, flexural strength and deflection at mid-span measurements were performed to evaluate the effect of composites. A significant improvement in flexural strength was observed from 45.97 to 54.23 and 57.28 MPa due to the inclusion of carbon fiber and carbon fiber with graphene for these composite bipolar plates. Similarly, a change from 3.03% to 5.2% and 5.85% was also observed for deflection at mid-span. The only addition of carbon fiber decreases electrical conductivity of bipolar plates. Graphene addition, however, enhances the in-plane and through plane conductivities range from 424.96 to 435.31 and from 115.71 to 130.17 S cm−1. The modification through carbon fiber increased corrosion current while no such effects are observed in case of modifications through graphene. The enhanced electrical conductivity of graphene modified bipolar plates, resulted superior device performance improved power density from 397 to 437 mW cm−2 and current density from 752 to 827 mA cm−2. Jiang et al. explored the use of graphene nanoplatelets (GNPs) as major filler contents for bipolar plates [218]. The poly phenylene sulphide (PPS) with CB was chosen as minor filler. Resultant PPS/GNP and PPS/CB/GNP nano-composites demonstrated monotonically increased flexure strength with increase in GNP contents. Moreover, improved permeability resistance and better in-plane conductivities for both nano-composites were observed. The electrical conductivities of the composites are displayed in Fig. 17 . The discussion concludes graphene based nanostructures as future prospects for bipolar plate applications in electrochemical energy conversion devices. 4.3 Graphene as proton exchange membrane In addition to its applications as electrocatalyst and bipolar plates, graphene have also been employed as electrolyte membrane in fuel cells. The following studies explore graphene as a promising alternative to the commercially used polymer membranes. Khilari and coworkers reported enhanced proton conductivity and strength of poly vinyl alcohol (PVA)-silicotungstic acid (STA)-graphene oxide (PVA-STA-GO) as separating membrane for microbial fuel cells [98]. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy shows improved conductivity of 0.065 S cm−1 for PVA-STA-GO from 0.046 S cm−1 of PVA-STA. Furthermore, modified composition results as an improved mechanical strength and higher power density of 1.19 W m−3. Hwang et al. synthesized graphene incorporated alkaline nanocomposite membranes and explored its electrochemical properties [219]. A nanocomposite anion exchange membrane was formed by PVA and graphene nanosheets through blending process. The homogeneous distribution of graphene improved the ionic conductivity by forming continuous and well-linked network of ionic channels. Graphene loading with 0.7 wt% in graphene/PVA nanocomposite membrane enhanced ionic conductivity by ∼126% and reduced methanol permeability by ∼55% as shown in Fig. 18 . The device showed a maximum power density increased by 148% by the introduction of graphene/PVA membrane. Moreover, a 73% improved tensile strength was achieved for the device. Therefore, graphene based nanocomposites are favorable choice for enhanced ionic conductivity and durable fuel cell devices. Ineista and coworkers used mixed matrix membrane for anion exchange, formed by chitosan(CS)/PVA hetero-structures doped with graphene oxide [220]. The uniform dispersion of GO over the CS:PVA polymer matrix exhibited increased thermal stability. The introduction of GO to CS:PVA degraded the ionic conductivity as GO do not change crystallinity of polymer matrix. On the other hand, hydrogen bonds between GO and CS:PVA reinforces the structure and acts as a barrier for alcohol permeability, reducing crossover effect. The device performance tests carried out under alkaline conditions revealed comparable results. The polarization curves of the device are shown in Fig. 19 . Studies suggest superior performance of graphene incorporated membranes for fuel cells for future commercial applications. In a recent report, Zhang et al. introduced novel GO/Nafion fiber based nano-hybrid proton migration membrane through electrospinning [221]. Nanofiber based PEM not only improved the proton conducting ability of the nano-hybrid but also provided proton conducting network, stability and lowered crossover effect. The addition of GO to Nafion increased the mechanical strength and electronic properties yet excessive amount of GO may result as proton blocking effect. Therefore, an optimized (0.1% GO/Nafion fiber) ratio was achieved for superior performance. Zakaria reported poly(vinyl alcohol)/GO composite with excellent PEM performance [222]. Incorporation of GO enhanced the PEM characteristics of poly(vinyl alcohol) in the similar way as reported by Zhang. However, optimized GO loading content was found to be 15%. The composite owned high proton exchange rate 9.5 × 10−3 at room temperature and 3.24 × 10−2 at 60 °C. The composite also demonstrated low fuel permeability and high power density 5.84 mW cm−2. In the similar way, Jang et al. investigated the effect of different compositions of sulfonated (poly-arylene ether ketone) and sulfonated GO (SGO) for PEM applications [223]. The composite reveal extraordinary morphology unveiling hydrophilic and hydrophobic sections for water activity, multiple pathways for rapid proton transfer mechanism and lowered proton transfer energy. The composite with 1.5 wt% GO attained high 124 × 10−3 S cm−2 conductivity and 19% water absorption capability. The studies conclude that nano-materials in composition with GO loading owe excellent characteristics for PEM applications. The insertion of GO not only enhance the electronic characteristics but also act as support to the materials for improved stability. 5 Conclusion and future prospects 2D geometry of carbon atoms in graphene has ascribed it with a unique spectrum of electrochemical properties. The broader electrochemically active area, fast carrier mobility and higher conductivity of graphene tunes the properties of Pt, Pt hybrids, graphene based novel 3D structures and metal free catalysts. The modification led to superior catalytic performance for oxygen reduction reactions and fuel oxidation reactions. Moreover, low sheet resistance, high durability and corrosion resistance of graphene makes it a good contender to be used for low corroding and highly stable bipolar plates. The reduced crossover effect and improved stability in polymer electrolyte membrane fuel cells is also achieved with graphene based separating membrane. Therefore, graphene and its derivatives for fuel cell applications are of prime interest and have promising applications for highly stable and efficient energy conversion devices. Despite the accelerated improvement in the performance of graphene incorporated fuel cell devices, enhanced electro-catalytic activity and durability of such energy systems is still a challenge hindering the scalable applications of graphene in fuel cells. Furthermore, graphene based electrocatalyst also demonstrate some technical and scientific issues. Since, the electrochemical characteristics of materials are shape and route dependent therefore a shape controlled fabrication route for metal nano-crystals on graphene flakes is desired. Although, non-supported nano-crystals have attained tunable morphology however only spherical nano-crystals with graphene support have been reported. Therefore, strategy to synthesize morphology tunable nano-crystals over graphene support for enhanced electro-catalytic activity and stability is critical issue. Additionally, the quality of graphene also plays important role in performance of fuel cell devices. Different reports have confirmed varying performance of same composition of graphene based electrocatalysts which may be partially attributed to varying qualities of graphene. The mechanism of improved catalytic performance of nano-crystals, stability and electronic interactions are still to be understood. Furthermore, the incorporation of heteroatoms i.e. N, B, S and P has widely been investigated theoretically and experimentally however some reports contradict the others. It is therefore necessary to understand the underlying mechanism in catalytic activity of heteroatom doped graphene based electrocatalysts to design high performance devices. The stability of nano-crystal electrocatalysts supported by graphene may also be enhanced in addition to intrinsic stability. Earlier reports proposed high durability of graphene layers due to graphitic basal plane structure. Since, highly graphitic phase of graphene lack defects, therefore graphene based composite materials owe excellent durability. The durability of graphene based electrocatalyst may also be enhanced by interaction strength at graphene/composite interface. Such interactions are responsible for high durability of N-Gr based metal catalysts due to strong coupling between N sites on graphene and metal nano-crystals. Likewise, similar approach may be adopted to overcome the performance and durability challenges of graphene as bipolar plates and proton exchange membrane for practical applications. Soc. 39 2018 715 721 Dr. Muhammad Zahir Iqbal has completed his PhD degree from Universitat Politècnica de Catalunya (UPC), Barcelona, Spain in 2014 and second PhD degree from Sejong University, Seoul, South Korea in 2014. Furthermore, he did his post-doctorate from Georgia State University, Atlanta, USA in 2015. Currently he is working as Assistant Professor at GIK Institute of Engineering Sciences and Technology. He has been the consecutive recipient of the Best Researcher of the year award at GIK Institute of Engineering Sciences and Technology since he joined. He is also succeeded in receiving the Research Productivity Award (RPA) of Pakistan. The research interest includes 2D Materials & Heterostructures, Solar & Fuel Cells, Sensors, Spintronic, Biochemical, Quantum & Optoelectronic Devices. Assad-Ur Rehman recently completed his MS in Engineering Sciences from GIK Institute of Engineering Sciences and Technology, Pakistan. Previously, he did his BS (Hons.) in Physics from University of Haripur, Pakistan. His research interests are carbon based materials for renewable energy conversion and storage devices. Saman Siddique is currently pursuing her MS in Engineering Sciences from GIK Institute of Engineering Sciences and Technology, Pakistan. Previously, she did her BS (Hons.) in Physics from University of Haripur, Pakistan. Her research interests are utilization of nanomaterials and their composites for efficient and cost-effective renewable energy conversion and storage devices.

coredata.dc:description: Novel characteristics of graphene have captured great attention of researchers for energy technology applications. Incorporation of graphene related hybrid and composite materials have demonstrated high performance and durability for fuel cell energy conversion devices. This article overviews graphene based materials for fuel cell technology applications such as electrodes additives, bipolar plates and proton conducting electrolyte membrane. The graphene dispersion over electrodes has revealed enhanced exposure of electrochemically active surface area for improved electro-catalytic activity towards fuel oxidation and oxidant reduction reactions. The issue of device stack durability and degraded performance due to corrosion of bipolar plates is discussed by incorporating graphene based materials. In proton exchange membrane devices, graphene as an electrolyte has shown an excellent performance towards high ionic conductivity and power density. The graphene incorporation in fuel cell devices has exhibited commendable performance and has bright future for commercial applications.
